docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

I like to drink

docs.title: Containers Overview
docs.text:
"Container-Technologie ist eine Methode der Virtualisierung, bei der Anwendungen zusammen mit ihren Abhängigkeiten in leichten, portablen und isolierten Umgebungen ausgeführt werden, die den Kernel des Host-Betriebssystems gemeinsam nutzen." -- ChatGPT

  • OS-Virtualisierung!
  • Container Runtime/Engine anstatt Hypervisor
  • Schneller/Schlanker aber weniger mächtig (zB HW Unterstützung)

docs.title: Vertreter der Container Technologie
docs.text: Aktuell sprechen wir meist von "Docker" oder OCI Container.

docs.title: Bare Metal vs VM vs Container
OCI Images
docs.text:
• VM Images sind HDD Snapshots die booten
  • Container Images sind Umgebungen in denen ein Prozess startet

Images sind definiert strukturierte Verzeichnisse (und Archive daraus), die aus bestimmten Files und Unterverzeichnissen verstehen.

  • Daten (bins/libs)
  • Konfiguration

$ cd example.com/app/
$ find . -type f
./index.json
./oci-layout
./blobs/sha256/3588d02542238316759cbf24502f4344ffcc8a60c803870022f335d1390c13b4
./blobs/sha256/4b0bc1c4050b03c95ef2a8e36e25feac42fd31283e8c30b3ee5df6b043155d3c

docs.title: Building Container Images / Dockerfile
docs.text: Source: https://docs.docker.com/build/guide/layers/

docs.title: Demo: NGINX Dockerfile
docs.text:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Welcome to My Static Site</title>
    <style>
        body {
            font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
            text-align: center;
            padding: 50px;
        }

        h1 {
            color: #333366;
        }

        p {
            color: #666;
            font-size: 1.2em;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Welcome to My Static Site</h1>
<p>This is a simple static website served by Nginx inside a Docker container.</p>
</body>
</html>

# Use the Nginx image from Docker Hub as the base image
FROM nginxinc/nginx-unprivileged:latest

# Copy the static website files to the Nginx server
COPY index.html /usr/share/nginx/html/index.html

# Expose port 80
EXPOSE 8080

# Start Nginx when the container launches
CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]

docker build -t my-website:latest .
docker run -p 8080:8080 my-website:latest

docs.title: Infrastructure-as-Code: Basics
docs.text:
Let's provision a virtual machine in the cloud, manually! :D
  • access https://portal.exoscale.com/
  • "Compute" -> "Instances" -> "ADD"
  • provide a name
  • select the template: "Linux Ubuntu 22.04 LTS 64-bit"
  • select zone: "AT-VIE-1"
  • select instance type: "Standard - Small"
  • select disk size: "50GB"

  • "ADD"

  • "Compute" -> "Security Groups" -> "ADD"

  • name: "public"
  • "ADD"
  • "Compute" -> "Security Groups" -> "public"
  • "ADD RULE" -> "SSH"
  • "Instances" (Tab) -> "ATTACH" -> "" Now let's reset the password and access the machine via SSH. Recap: What do we see under the hood? 
    # show me all attached block devices
lsblk

# show me all filesystems
df -h

# show me all network interfaces
ip a

# are we a VM?
systemd-detect-virt
dmesg | grep -i kvm
lscpu
# Virtualization features:
#   Virtualization:        VT-x
#   Hypervisor vendor:     KVM
#   Virtualization type:   full

docs.text:
• What's the issue with "UI" clicking?

    • Reproducability

  • GitHub create account docu
  • Git Tutorial
  • Questions? eMail me asap.

    • assessment criteria:

    • deadline: 25% - submitted in time?
    • content: 25% - well written and complete?
    • visualization: 25% - sources, pictures, examples?
    • presentation: 25% - convincingly presented or simply read off

docs.title: Before We Begin
docs.text: Welcome to Virtualization Basics :-)

docs.title: What You’ll Learn
docs.text: • Basics of virtualization

docs.title: What You'll Need
docs.text:
• a notebook
  • access to the internet
  • a thirst for knowledge, a clear mind and an insatiable urge to learn

docs.title: Further Reading
docs.text:
• KodeKloud
  • Linux Foundation LFS151x

docs.title: Virtualization Basics (40min)
docs.text:
• What is virtualization?
  • Simulation vs. Emulation - is that important for virtualization?
  • Why virtualization?

brainstorm in groups, four quadrants:

  • What can be virtualized?
  • Where do you see virtualization in your daily life?
  • Advantages
  • Disadvantages

docs.title: Compute / Network / Storage (60min)
docs.text:
Working out in groups:

  • Compute virtualization + OS virtualization
  • Network virtualization
  • Storage virtualization

Address at least these points:

  • What's the matter? What is virtualized? How does it work roughly?
  • Important types, protocols, species, representatives?
  • Advantages/disadvantages and potential?
  • Common products, projects, tools, vendors?
  • Where and whatfor is it used?

docs.title: Server Virtualization
docs.text:
• Type1 Hypervisor/VMM
  • HW virtualization on bare metal
  • KVM, Microsoft Hyper-V and VMware vSphere
  • Type2 Hypervisor/VMM
  • HW virtualization on OS
  • VMware Workstation and Oracle VirtualBox
  • Full virtualization vs. paravirtualization
  • OS virtualization
  • Docker, LXC
  • Performance impact

docs.title: Storage Virtualization
docs.text:
• DAS - Direct Attached Storage
  • USB
  • SATA / SCSI
  • NVME
  • SAN - Storage Area Network (Block)
  • LUN
  • FC, FCoE, iSCSI
  • NAS (File)
  • NFS / SMB(CIFS)

docs.title: Network Virtualization
docs.text:
• VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network)
  • VLAN ID, Tagging, Trunk, Broadcast Domain
  • VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN)
  • VXLAN Segment, Tunnel Endpoint (VTEP), Network Identifier (VNI), Encapsulation
  • SDN (Software Defined Networking)
